loans.name: Doung

texts.en:
Fishing is the most important part of 40-year-old Doung S.’s daily work. She and her husband have been living on a fishing boat on the river for more than nine years. This couple wakes up every morning, drives their boat toward the middle of the river and then fishes. After the fishing is done, they hurry to bring their fish to the market and sell to their regular buyers on credit. They collect their money after their buyers sell all of the fish that they bought.

Doung S. and her husband have seven single children, two of whom earn a profit in the fishing business as well. Doung S. will use her loan to purchase nets, a boat and other fishing implements for catching more fish.

loans.use: To purchase nets, a boat and other fishing implements for catching more fish

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en: Zubaida lives in Kasur, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its leather industry. She lives in the Rasoolpura area in a three-room brick house with her family. She is 31 years old and has six children. Her eldest son works for a private organization while the others are studying and attending a local school. Her husband is a cobbler by profession and manufactures shoes. He makes contracts with different factories and shoe stores and fills their orders on time to earn profit. He has another business of making rope which is used to make a local bed called a charpae (a cot). Zubaida also helps her husband financially by making embroidered shawls. She is very good at her work and prepares a good number of shawls every month which she sells to different shops in the city. She is a very responsible lady and also manages her household work very well. Zubaida has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, to improve her husband’s rope-making business. With this loan, he will buy a rope-making machine and thread that will help him make rope in larger quantities and sell at a higher profit. He has been in business for the past six years, and Zubaida is hopeful that a loan investment will make her husband’s business more profitable and will increase his income. Zubaida is a new loan applicant of Asasah and hopes to bring positive financial changes to her family. In the photo, the lady holding a book (an Asasah passbook) is Zubaida.

loans.use: to buy a rope-making machine and thread for a rope-making business

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 13 people, each of whom will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family's living standard. Chanthy, the village bank president selected by the other members, is a 52-year-old widow with five children, one a wedding beautician, another a garment factory worker, another a print laborer, and remaining two students in the local public school.

Chanthy is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land upon which she grows rice, selling part of the crop and using the rest to feed her family. Wishing to begin an additional business, Chanthy is requesting a loan to buy some piglets to breed.

loans.use: to buy some piglets

texts.en: Pacita F. is from the village of San Juan, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Pacita is married and has five adult children. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and instant noodles. Pacita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Pacita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pacita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Pacita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Pacita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily-use products in the local community.

In 2011, Reychard joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 7000 Philippine pesos (PHP) that will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be Reychard's first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.name: My

texts.en: My M. is 34 years old married man who makes a daily profit by selling. His wife, Sor Eang, is 33, and sells rattan cupboards in her village, which is in the province of Kompong Tom. The couple has two children, both in school. My M. always uses his motor-trailer as vehicle to pick up his item to sell in and around his community. Unluckily, his motor-trailer was broke during driving. My M. is worried about his bed-selling business because of his motor-trailer. Accordingly, he would like to request a loan to buy a new motor-trailer to replace the broken one so he can continue his business as he did before.

loans.use: to buy a new motor-trailer

loans.name: Mrs. Yav Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Yav is the village bank president selected by the 16 people who comprise this village bank loan. The members will use their portion of the loan for various purposes in order to improve their families' living standards.

Born in 1954 and the mother of a child employed as a laborer, Yav and her husband Sen own a half-hectare plot of land upon which they grow rice, some of which they sell and some of which they use to feed their family. Wishing to start an additional enterprise, Yav is requesting a loan to buy some piglets and pig food for breeding.

loans.use: to buy some piglets and pig food

loans.name: Policarpio

texts.en:
Policarpio U. is from the village of Santa Clara, Aritao, in the province of Nueva Vizcaya. He is 51 years old, is married, and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Policarpio owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Policarpio has been engaged in his business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 35,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per harvest.

Policarpio joined ASKI in 2011 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his first loan from ASKI. Policarpio plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of his immediate family.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. (ASKI) is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mrs. Sot Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people, who selected Mrs. Sot to become a village bank president, will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families to a higher standard of living. 

Mrs. Sot weaves silk cloth at her home where she can earn some money to support her family. Her business is getting on well and she wants to expand. So to improve this purpose, Mrs. Sot is requesting a loan to buy more silk for weaving. Her husband, Mr. Muk, is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land where he can cultivate rice. He sells part of the rice yield and supports his family with the rest of the rice. This couple supports five children, one of whom is a Chinese translator, another is a seamstress in garment factory, two attend local public school, and the youngest one is 7 years old.

She has a small piece of land next to the house. She started using it to grow seasonal vegetables and sell them to neighbors. The number of clients is growing and this helps her improve the project.

Intesar took a loan from FATEN to grow in a larger space of land and start packaging her crops for sale. Intesar's husband appears in the picture here instead of her, as she is a conservative woman.

loans.name: Mr. Kang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Kang, who was born in 1955, is a village bank president. He has been selected by the eleven members who make up a village bank loan. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families to a higher standard of living. 

Mr. Kang is a vegetable seller in local market where he can earn some income to support his family. Currently, he wants to expand because his business is doing well. S. to improve this purpose, Mr. Kang is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables for resale. His wife, Mrs. Nam, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can grow both rice and vegetables to sell to support her family. They support three children, two of whom are employed in garment factories, the youngest one is studying in local public school.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses has a poultry farm in Murang'a town in central Kenya. He has been in the farming business for 12 years now and employs one farmhand. He sells his eggs locally. He mainly depends on the income from his farm for the basic needs of his family.

Moses is 34 years old and married with four school-aged children who all attend school.

He has requested a loan of 70,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo for poultry farming. The extra income from the sale of eggs will help improve his family's livelihood. He says that the high cost of poultry feed and diseases have been his greatest challenges. He hopes to increase his egg production in the next five years.

loans.use: Poultry farming.

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran lives in a small city in Punjab, Pakistan called Kasur. Kasur is famous for its tannery industry. She has been living there with her family in a two-room brick house for the past 10 years. She is 27 years old and operates a utensils-selling business. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. She has no child yet; that’s why she spends her spare time doing her household responsibilities. Her brother and sister also live with her and contribute financially by doing work. Both of them are also involved in the same business. Bashiran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother who wants to expand his utensils-selling business. With the loan, he will buy utensils of steel and plastic that will allow him to sell in larger quantity and make more profits. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Bashiran is confident that a loan investment will bring more profits to him and will expand his business. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a good experience for her.  

Note: In the photo, the lady with a raised hand is Bashiran.

loans.use: To buy steel and plastic utensils to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Koem Than Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group loan is for ten people who will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. They are all seeking to improve their standard of living. Mrs. Koem Than was selected by the members to be the group leader. She was born in 1978. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where she grows rice. When she harvests the rice, she sells some of it, and she uses some of it for her family. Her husband, Mr. Korb, is a motorcycle taxi driver. Though they try to work hard, they earn only a small income. To improve their situation, Mrs. Koem Than is asking for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food in order to start a new business breeding pigs. She is the mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Jyldyz's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyz I. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Kochkor, a nice village in the Isykul region. She is 37 years old and married to a taxi driver. Together they are bringing up two sons and a daughter, all of whom study at school. 

In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Jyldyz sells convenience goods, stationary and home products.  She started this activity ten years ago with the initial investment of 1,000 KGS and now she earns approximately $254 a month. 

With money received from the loan Jyldyz would purchase more products in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to improve the family’s living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell.

Dugenia N. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old. Dugenia is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, instant noodles and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $162 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Dugenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Dugenia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Meas Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people have requested a village bank loan.  Each borrower will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose, to improve the family's standard of living.  The members have selected Mrs. Meas to be a village bank president. 

Mrs. Meas,  who was born in 1972, sells vegetables and fruit door-to-door to earn some profit to support her family. Now she has a problem because her motorcycle for transportation is broken. To improve this condition, Mrs. Meas is asking for a loan to fix the motorcycle.  With the rest of the loan she is going to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. Her husband, Mr. Vuthy, is a construction worker. They have five children.  One is a seamstress in garment factory,  three attend local public school, and the youngest one is 3 months old.

loans.use: to fix the motorcycle

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion G. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Concepcion is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, beverages and eggs in the local community. She is also buying and selling coconuts for copras (dried coconut meat used for oil production). She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $150 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Concepcion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Concepcion is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos, 30, is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for ten years now and sells his maize, milk and beans locally. He also earns income from procuring and selling sand to the local market.

He has requested a loan of 30,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo for his poultry farm. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him meet his basic needs. He hopes to have established a breeding farm in the next five years. His primary challenges have been poor market prices for his farm produce and competition.

loans.use: to maintain his poultry farm.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 31 years old and is a married woman with two children. The oldest child is 7. 
 
She is a fish seller working in Trinidad, Bohol. She has been in this business for a year. She earns about $63 per month doing this fish selling.
 
This loan will be used to buy more fish, plastic bags and a weighing scale. In the future, Arlene hopes to grow her business and have her children finish college.

loans.use: to buy more fish, plastic bags and a weighing scale.

loans.name: Fikret

texts.ru: Fikret D. 32 qoda. On jenat i imeyet odnoqo rebonka. Fikret yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuili qoroda i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. On uje 4 qoda kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji obuvi. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi rasshirit pomesheniye dlya toqo chtobi umestiti bolshe tovara dlya prodaji v svoyom magazine. Fikret ranshe rabotal prodavcom v magazine svoyeqo dyadi a potom reshil otkrit svoy magazin.
texts.en: Fikret D. is 32 years old. He is married and has one child. Fikret is an internally displaced person and has been relocated from the town of Fuzili and now lives in the Fuzili region together with his family. He has been in the business of selling shoes for four years now. At this time he needs 2000 AZN to expand his store space to be able to house more merchandise for resale. Fikret has worked as a salesperson before in the store of his uncle and later decided to open his own store.

loans.use: to expand the space of his shoe store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophal Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of sixteen people who have selected Mrs. Sophal to be a village bank president. All members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mrs. Sophal, born in 1967, is a farmer who owns a 5-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice.  She sells part of her rice yield, and with the rest she supports her family.  Mr. Pheun is a duck breeder who can earn some money from selling duck eggs.  He also owns a threshing machine for renting to farmers.  Mrs. Sophal wants to buy a harvest machine to start a new business, but her savings is not sufficient to support this.  Mrs. Sophal is seeking a loan to buy a harvest machine for renting to farmers. She is a mother of three children, one of whom helps with his father’s business, while the others attend local public school.

loans.use: to buy a harvest machine

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette D. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Janette is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling snack foods, candies, canned goods and biscuits in the local community. She is also buying and selling coconuts for copras (dried coconut meat used for oil production). She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $188 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Janette joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Janette is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods to sell.

loans.name: Portia

texts.en:
Portia M. is a trader working at Abee near the fishing town of Elmina.  She is married to a taxi driver and has one child.  Portia sells drinks and powder as well as hand bags and kitchen utensils.  She has been doing this job for 6 years now. 

Portia uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Her plan is to expand her business.  Therefore she would like to purchase more bags and utensils for sale.  Portia hopes to increase her profits to reinvest into her business, but to also take care of her children so they can enjoy a good education.

loans.use: To purchase more bags and utensils for sale.

loans.name: Barchaiym's Group

texts.en:
Barchaiym U., 54, is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Kochkor, a small village in Isykul region. Unfortunately she is a widow.  She has a son, 11, who studies in school.  In order to earn money to meet the family needs Barchaiym breeds livestock and then resells them after fattening.  She has been doing this for 25 years.  In this way she earns 4,200 KGS per month.  With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase two livestock animals for breeding.  In the future she wants to provide her son with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase two livestock animals.

loans.name: Mrs. Thoeun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun, born in 1982,  has been selected as village bank president by nineteen members who make up a village bank loan,  Each borrower will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mrs. Thoeun is a Khmer cake seller and a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she grows rice, selling pA. of the yield and using the rest to support her family. In the rice field, she has some problems because her field has infertile soil. To improve the rice production, Mrs.Thoeun is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. Her husband, Mr. C. Ney, is a farming laborer and fisherman.  He also works leaves of palm trees to make roofs to sell to support his family. This couple supports two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica E., who lost her husband and is the mother of three children, sells both secondhand clothing and local doughnuts in a village near the coastal town of Elmina.  Denied the opportunity of receiving any formal education, Veronica is determined to provide a chance for her children to go to school. In addition to school fees, books and uniforms for her children, she pays for the basic needs of her family. 

With the help of the loan, Veronica hopes to increase her profit by expanding her business. To achieve this goal she wants to purchase more used clothing and extend the variety of clothes she sells.

loans.use: With the help of the loan, Veronica hopes to be able to increase her profit by expanding her business.

loans.name: Ellyn

texts.en:
Ellyn B., from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province, is 27 years old, separated from her spouse, and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Ellyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, breads, canned goods and snack foods in the local community. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Ellyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and instant noodles, Ellyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and instant noodles

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi A. has a small shop, where she sells food items such as tomatoes, onions, eggs, and other foodstuffs, at Abee near the fishing town of Elmina . She has been running this shop for more than eight years. Naomi uses her income to pay for her accommodations, utility bills, and food.  Naomi is applying for a loan because she would like to expand her business. Her plan is to buy more goods and increase the variety of goods sold at her shop to meet the needs of her customers. She will reinvest her profits into her business to keep it growing.

loans.use: To purchase more goods and increase the variety of goods sold at her shop

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita Z., from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province, is 52 years old, separated from her spouse, and has six grown children. To make a living, Merlita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, noodles, detergents, canned goods and toothpaste in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Merlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods, Merlita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: My

texts.en:
The three people shown in the picture are My K., her husband, and her lovely child. My K., 38 years old, is a humble mother who has three single children who attend school. She has been cultivating rice for many years on her farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. Her husband is a fruit juice seller along the road using a motor-cart. 

My K.’s husband's business is now running very well because he sells his items at a reasonable price. He wishes to invest more capital to buy fruit for making fruit juice in larger quantities than before but he has a problem with financial resources. That is why My K. seeks a loan from Kiva through HKL.

loans.use: to buy some fruit to make fruit juice to sell.

loans.name: Kalembubu's Group

texts.en:
Kalembubu K. is the leader of this group. She is 58 and married to a builder.  Together with her husband she is bringing up two sons and two daughters. The first son is handicapped; the older daughter studies at university and the other children are at school.  Kalembubu herself works as a cleaner at school. 

In order to earn additional money she breeds livestock. She started this activity seven years ago and now she earns 2000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to increase the number of livestock.  In the future Kalembubu wants to provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Retemta

texts.en:
Retemta has been practicing mixed farming for the last seventeen years in Kitale town in western Kenya. She has employed one farmhand and sells her milk, eggs, maize and beans locally. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to cater for the basic needs of her family.

Retemta is 48 years old and married with seven children aged between 6 and 27. Four of the children are currently attending school.

She has requested a loan of 30,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to start poultry farming. The additional income from this loan will enable her to cater for the basic needs of her family.  Her biggest challenge has been lack of markets for her products and also the rampart diseases which affect her production.

loans.use: To start poultry farming.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. lives in Abee which is a community near the coastline near Elmina. Her job is to sell locally-made body powder and soap as well as oil and yams. She sells these goods by carrying them on her head in large bowl. She then walks the streets in her village. 

Efua has three children she is taking care of all by herself because she is divorced and does not get any support form the children’s father. Most of the money she makes with her business is being used to take care of the basic needs of her family. She also sends her children to school which means she has to pay for books and other learning material. 

To be able to provide the opportunity of education for her children she would like to expand her business. In order to achieve this goal Efua wants to buy more goods to be able to sell more and as a result increase her profit.

loans.use: to buy more goods such as locally-made body powder, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma M. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Alma is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying & selling used clothing or "ukay-ukay" in the local community. She is also making and selling snacks like sweet potato & banana "cues". Alma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients like ripe bananas & sugar and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Alma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients like ripe bananas & sugar and as working capital.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba G. is a "kenkey" (fermented corn dough) seller at Abee near Elmina. Kenkey is a dish made from corn dough wrapped in corn husk. In the picture you can see her preparing it. She sells the kenkey with tomato sauce and fish. Aba has one child and is married to a carpenter. She has been selling kenkey for the past seven years and wants to use the money from the loan to boost her business. 

Aba's plan is to buy more needed ingredients to be able to prepare more kenkey and satisfy more customers. The profit she makes is being used to assist her husband in the payment of school fees for their child as well as paying for learning materials and a uniform. Together they also take care of other basic need of the family. The hope connected to the loan is to expand her business and provide a safe future for her child.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to prepare more fermented corn dough.

loans.name: Mrs. Rem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people who make up a village bank loan will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve each family's standard of living.  The borrowers have selected Mrs. Rem to be a village bank president. 

Mrs. Rem is a congee seller who earns some profit to support her family while her husband, Mr. Bet, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where he grows rice.  He sells part of the yield, and uses the rest of the rice to support his family. In the rice field, Mrs. Rem faces obstacles because her field is infertile soil and it has a lot of insects.   To improve rice production, Mrs. Rem is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. She is a mother of three children.  One is a singer, while the others attend local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture above, Mrs. Chhin H., is a 37-year-old farmer residing in the city of Phnom Penh. She plants rice; that is her annual business. Her husband works in construction. 

Mrs. Chhin H. is looking for a $300 loan as capital to support her farming business. She will use the loan to buy many sacks of fertilizer and rice seed. With any remaining funds, she will repair her old house. Mrs. Chhin H. has seven children who still living under her roof till the present time. One of them is employed as a sewing worker in a factory and has a formal salary per month.

loans.use: To buy many sacks of fertilizer, rice seed, and repair her old house.

loans.name: Elna

texts.en:
Elna R. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Elna is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Elna owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making & selling snacks & other delicacies like "siopao" (steamed buns), banana "cue" (deep-fried banana on a stick), & sweet potato delight in the local community. Elna has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Elna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elna is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like sugar & bananas needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HHSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients such as sugar & bananas to make products for sale.

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Togetherness” group from Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Ibrahim C. is the leader of this group. The 35-year-old is married to a businesswoman and they have one child. Ibrahim has been a businessman for 6 years now. He sells groundnuts/peanuts. With his share of this loan, he will buy groundnuts/peanuts wholesale to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts/peanuts wholesale.

loans.name: Mrs Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs Mom is the village bank president who has been selected by the thirteen people who make up this village bank loan. Each will use their portion of the loan to improve their family's standard of living. Mrs Mom was born in 1970. She is the mother of two children who are attending the local public school. She is a mat-maker and farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where she can cultivate rice. She sells some of the rice and uS. the rest to feed her family. Her husband, Mr Lorn, is a construction worker. Mrs Mom wants to breed some pigs, but she does not have the money to do this. So she is requesting a loan to buy three piglets and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy three piglets and fertilizer.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort Y. bakes bread which she also sells. She lives in Abee which is near the fishing town of Elmina. After baking the bread, she sells it, presenting it on her head as you can see on the picture, walking the streets of Abee. Comfort is a widow, responsible for seven children who live with her. Sadly her husband has passed away so they rely entirely on her. 

Comfort has been selling bread and other provisions for eight years now.  She expects to boost her business with the loan to be able to take better care of her children. Besides the basic household expenses she is also covering the costs for her children’s education like books, uniforms and other learning materials. She plans to increase the amount of baked bread to be able to sell more and increase her profit as a result.

loans.use: to bake more bread for sale in her town.

loans.name: Sokhoen's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has six members who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' standards of living. 

Mrs. Sokhoen is the group leader who has been selected by the other members. She was born in 1980. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are attending local public school. The youngest is 3 years old.
 
She and her husband, Mr. Mul, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice. They sell some part of the rice yield and the rest of the rice they keep to support their family. He is also a construction worker. 

They try to work hard, but their income is still only a little. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sokhoen is asking for a loan to buy some piglets and some pig food to start a new pig-breeding business. With the rest of the loan she is going to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy some piglets and pig food

loans.name: Serwah

texts.en:
Serwah K. is a fish seller at the fishing village of Abee near Elmina. Before selling the fish she smokes it in a specially built oven. She has been doing this job for the past six years now. Her husband left her and she lives alone.

Serwah uses her income to take care of herself and pay for basic household expenses. Serwah wishes to use this loan to to buy more fish, and to buy more materials to smoke the fish, and hopes to reinvest any additional capital gained into her business. Her hope is to increase her profit by selling more fish, and to be able to save some money for the time when she won’t be capable to work anymore.

loans.use: to buy more fish to resell, and to buy more materials to smoke the fish

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita N. is from the village of Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 42 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Conchita runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, and sells products such as shampoo, soap, snacks, canned goods and candy to members of the local community. She also sells a variety of blankets. Conchita has had her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).

In 2008, Conchita joined Kiva field partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conchita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI, used to to purchase additional inventory and as  working capital. Conchita is requesting this loan of 17,000 PHP, her sixth from HSPFI, with plans to use it to buy additional products to sell, such as canned goods and beverages. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages, and other products to sell at a small variety store

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rabqa's Group

texts.en:
Rabqa is married to A. M. who is a farmer. He works in the fields and grows different seasonal crops.  He is very hardworking, and works 8-10 hours every day in the fields. Mostly, he grows cotton which he sells to different factories on order.

Rabqa lives with her family in Khanewal in a two-room brick house. Khanewal is a small Pakistani city known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Shanti Nagar for 20 years.   Rabqa is 47 years old and has no children. She spends her time by staying at home and taking care of household responsibilities. 

Rabqa has applied for a loan from Kiva field partner Asasah for her husband’s agriculture business. With the loan he will buy seed, and fertilizer to get better results from his crops. He has eight years of experience in his work and Rabqa hopes that this loan will help him get more from his work and increase his profits.  This is Rabqa's third loan from Asasah.  Up to now, she has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed any meetings. 

Note: In the photo that accompanies this profile, Rabqa is the woman at right who is holding an Asasah Passbook.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer for farming

loans.name: Jacinto

texts.en:
Jacinto C. is from the village of Sta. Clara Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 55 years old, married and has three adult children. To make a living, Jacinto owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jacinto has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Jacinto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jacinto is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be Jacinto's first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K. is 55 years old, married, and has three children, one of whom attends school and two of whom are working.  Sok K. makes her living by planting rice on her own farmland, which she has been doing for over 10 years. Her husband is a domestic construction foreman. Sok K. wants to build one small room in her house for her relatives or others guests to use when they come to visit.  She is requesting a loan to purchase construction materials such as cement, brick, sand, iron, and other necessary equipment for building.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Levenia

texts.en:
Levenia M. is from the village of Batinay, Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 32 years old. Levenia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Levenia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling firewood, bananas & coconuts in the local community. She is also providing services such as pedicure & manicure. Levenia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Levenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Levenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Levenia is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional firewood & bananas to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Levenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional firewood & bananas to sell.

location.town: Batinay, Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Or

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Art Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Art, who was born in 1977, is a village bank president who has been selected by 17 people who make up a village bank loan. The members will use their portions of the loan in different ways to improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. Sam Art is a sausage seller in the local market where she can earn some profit to support her family. She is the mother of five children, two of whom are construction workers, and the others are enrolled in local public school. 

Her husband, Mr. Vuthy, is a construction worker. 

In the present, her house is not comfortable to live in because it does not have a lavatory. S. to improve this condition, Mrs. Sam Art is applying for a loan to build a lavatory.

loans.use: to build a lavatory

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina B. is the owner of a provisions store in Abee near the coastal town of Elmina. Among the goods she sells are drinks, washing powder and some foodstuffs. For the past eight years her business has been growing slowly but steadily. 

Due to the loan Georgina is hoping for a boost. She would like to offer her customers a wider range of goods and increase her profit as a result. She is not married and takes care of her child all by herself. She hopes to expand her business and increase her profit to be able to take better care of her child.

loans.use: to be able to offer her customers a wider range of goods.

loans.name: Cesario

texts.en:
Cesario B. is from the village of Sta. Clara Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 50 years old. Cesario is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Cesario owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Cesario has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Cesario joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cesario is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cesario from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Rustam yavlyayetsya IDP personom one pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey mamoy. Rustam F.  31 qod. On ne jenat i ne imeyet detey. Rustam uje 4 qoda kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji kasetov, diskov i t.d. On seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN  dlya toqo chtobi kupit pobolshe novix diskov i kasetov kotoriyi trebuyutsya sredi pokupateley, eto v osnovnom diski znamenitix pevcov i kaseti so smeshnimi video, no takje on xochet na eti dengi kupit i sdelat sebe steklanniye polki qde budet lazlajivat eti diski , tak kaka vi videte na risunke on prodayet diski v korobkax. Mama Rustama uje 2 qoda kak boleyet  i on vse vremya uxajivayet za ney i mnoqo rabotoyet chtobi oplatiti lecheniye materi.
texts.en: Rustam F. is an Internally Displaced person from the town of Fuzuli. Now he livesi n the Fuzuli Region together with his mother. Rustam F. is 31 year old. He is single without children. For the last four years, Rustam has been selling videotapes, CD/DVD disks etc. At present he needs 2,000 AZN in order to buy merchandise for resale. Rustam’s mother has been ailing for two years. He always takes care of her and works a lot in order to cover her medical expenses

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for resale

loans.name: Malyn

texts.en:
Malyn E. is from the village of Bolihon, Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 32 years old. Malyn is married and has two children. To make a living, Malyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, instant noodles & beverages in the local community. Malyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month for these activities. In the picture are Malyn & her younger son.

In 2008, Malyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Malyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Malyn is requesting a new loan of 26,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods & beverages. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Malyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods & beverages.

location.town: Bolihon, Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Orienta

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa A. is a very hard-working woman who is engaged in multiple businesses. Adjoa has a small provisions store where she also sells smoked fish. Besides that, she works as a waitress in a bar. Besides being a hard worker, she is also a mother to four children whom she takes care of. 

Adjoa uses her income to make sure her family is well cared for.  Adjoa will use the loan to purchase more goods for her provision store to expand her business.  Her hope is to be able to increase her profit and make sure her children can keep going to school.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for her provisions store.

loans.name: Mrs. Nor Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 15 people who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. Nor was born in 1968 and she has been selected group leader by the other members. 

She and her husband, Mr. Saram, are teachers in the local school, where they can get a low salary to support their family. She is a dessert seller, too. 

This couple supports three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is enrolled in local public school, and the small one is 5 years old. 

In order to improve their family income, Mrs. Nor is seeking a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: to buy some piglets

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
Armando F. is from the village of Sta. Clara Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 45 years old. Armando is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Armando owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Armando has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2011, Armando joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Armando is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Armando from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua E. lives in Abee near Elmina with her husband and two children. Every day she walks the streets of her community to sell cosmetics and other items which she carries around on her head in a large bowl. Ekua uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  She would like to use the money from the loan to expand her business. Her plan is to buy more goods and satisfy more customers. By investing she promises herself an increased profit. She wants to save some of the money she will make to provide her children the opportunity to enjoy a good education.

loans.use: to buy more products to sell.

loans.name: Sreyneang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreyneang O. (in the photo with her loom) is 30 years old and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Ang is 39 years old. They live in a village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2000 and have two daughters. One is in school and another one is still young.   

Sreyneang is a weaver. Her husband is a security guard. She is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn B. is from the village of Salinas Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 33 years old. Marilyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia C. is from the village of Laturan, Libona, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Cynthia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cynthia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling  rice per kilogram & animal feed & farm-related products in the local community. Cynthia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cynthia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cynthia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Cynthia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like sacks of rice & animal feeds. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Cynthia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like sacks of rice & animal feeds.

loans.name: Mrs. Thul Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The 16 people  who make up this village bank loan have selected Mrs. Thul to be the village bank president. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes by which they can improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. Thul owns a general store in the local village where she sells groceries to earn some profit to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. Thus, in order to improve her daily income, Mrs. Thul is seeking a loan to buy more groceries for resale.

 Her husband, Mr. Sophat, is a farmer and a vice village chief. They support four children; one is a laborer, and the others are students.

loans.use: to buy more groceries for resale

loans.name: Raphonsel

texts.en:
Raphonsel B. is from the village of Sta. Clara Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 33 years old. Raphonsel is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Raphonsel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Raphonsel has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Raphonsel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raphonsel is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Raphonsel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Sek

texts.en:
Sek S. is able to earn a living by working at a private company which is in charge of driving trucks in and around Phnom Penh City. He has been working in this position since 2009 and getting a monthly salary. He has a life partner in his wife who is a clothing seller in the marketplace. Sek S.’s wife has managed her investment carefully and has attracted a large number of customers due to her communications skills. 

In order to better meet her customers' demands, she wishes to purchase more clothing to sell. Because of this, Sek S. decided to ask for a loan from Kiva. This couple has given birth to three children; two are single and the other one is married and living independently.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing for his wife to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new breeds of pigs

loans.name: Sreynak's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreynak is a group leader who has been selected by four members who make up this group loan. All the members will use their portions of the loan for different purposes that can improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. Sreynak was born in 1977. She is a widow with four children, two of whom are employed in garment factories while the others are studying in local public school. 

She is a pig breeder who is able to earn some profit to support her family. Recently, she has had a problem because she does not have money to buy pig food. So to improve this business, Mrs. Sreynak is asking for a loan to buy pig food for breeding her pigs.

loans.use: to buy pig food

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz belongs to a small city of Punjab province of Pakistan called Khanewal. It is famous for its agriculture industry. She lives there in a 2-room brick house in the area of Shanti Nagar with her husband and four sons. She shifted here 25 years ago. Her husband’s name is G. and he is a daily wage laborer. His income is not enough for the whole family, andthat’s why Mumtaz started a clothes sewing business to share the financial burden with him. She is very skillful and earns a good profit from her work.

Due to financial constraints, she couldn’t provide education facilities to her elder children. Her eldest son works on monthly wage. The next two are also daily wage laborers. Her youngest son is studying in class 6. 

Mumtaz is a very active lady; besides her business, she also performs her responsibilities as a housewife very well. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine which will help her finish her work quickly and earn better profits.  

She has been doing this business for the past 10 years. She is sure that she will be able to do a lot better by purchasing a new sewing machine. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and knows her responsibilities very well. In previous loan years, she has always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. This is her 3rd loan application. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Mumtaz.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora L. is from the village of Barangay 4, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 64 years old. Leonora is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Leonora owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling used clothing, called "ukay-ukay" in the local community. Her husband is driving their "trisikad" (three-wheeled transport vehicle). Leonora has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as used clothing. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as used clothing.

loans.name: Mrs. Lina Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fifteen people who will each use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mrs. Lina is the village bank president and she has been selected by the other members. She was born in 1982. She owns a general store in the local village where she earns some profit in order to support her family.  She is also a pig breeder. Since her business is going well from time-to-time, she wants to expand. Therefore, in order to improve this business, Mrs. Lina is seeking a loan to buy more piglets. Her husband, Mr. Mut, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where he grows rice, which he does not sell, to support his family. This couple supports three children, one of whom is enrolled in a local public school, but the others are too small to work or study.

loans.use: to buy more piglets

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua N. is street vendor at Jukwa near Abura which lies close to Cape Coast. She is married to a farmer and she assists him in the payment of school fees and expenses for their five children as well as utility bills. 

Ekua went to senior high school and has been doing her job for 25 years now. Besides the locally-produced doughnuts you can see in the picture, she also sells meat pies and bread. 

Ekua would like to use the money from the loan to invest into her business and see it grow. The newly-earned profit will be used to further boost the business and also to provide learning materials for the children.

loans.use: Ekua would like to use the money of the loan to invest into her business and see it grow.

loans.name: Banina

texts.fr: Dame Banina  a 48 et est mariée. Elle a 6 enfants à charge.  Elle a  reçu  de Wages un crédit qu’elle a déjà remboursé. Pour participer au foyer, elle fait le commerce  de pagnes . Elle a commencé cette activité en 1989 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Elle revend ensuite au marché de Nukafu. Elle demande un crédit pour se réapprovisionner et satisfaire plus de clients.
texts.en: Banina is 48 years old and married. She has six children in her care. She has already had a loan from Wages which she has repaid. In order to contribute to the household, she trades in "pagnes" (a West African term for highly decorative pieces of fabric). She began this activity in 1989 and gets her supplies at the large market in Lomé. She then resells at the market in Nukafu. She is requesting a loan to get fresh supplies and satisfy more customers.

loans.use: To buy "pagnes"

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua M. is a "banku" (fermented dough) seller in Jukwa near Abura. "Banku" is made from corn and cassava dough. She prepares the banku several times a week and sells it afterwards in front of her house with fried fish. For the three years the business went well but she is hoping for a breakthrough with the help of the loan. 

Ekua will use the money to buy more corn in order to prepare larger quantities of banku. Ekua is married to a farmer and takes care of five dependents. Therefore she will use most of her newly earned profit to take care of her family. She went to school herself and wants her children to enjoy the same privilege but learning materials and school fees cost money. That’s why she aims to assist her husband more in these payments. With a growing business she knows this will be possible.

loans.use: to buy more corn to prepare larger quantities of "banku".

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas M. is a sixty-year-old woman who lives in the capital, Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. She is a widow and the mother of three children. One of her kids is married and lives in their own house. 

Meas M.’s son is a car driver in a local company, earning salary of around $150 per month; he contributes to covering the family's expenses. Meas M. owns a sewing machine that she uses to sew clothing for villagers for daily revenue. She has a daughter who works with her in sewing clothing. 

Meas M. says that her existing motorbike always needs to be repaired, and she often spends a lot of money to fix it. In order to reduce repair expenses, Meas M. will use her loan to buy a new motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle to replace her broken one.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia N. has been working as a street vendor for 22 years now. Every day she walks the streets of her home town Jukwa near Abura and sells fried fish, meat pies and pastries. Afia has received senior high education. She is married and has four children. Her husband is an agriculture officer. Afia assists her husband in taking care of the family. 

Her loan will be used to buy an oven for her pastry business. Preparing the pastries herself and in larger quantities will enable her to increase her profit. For the coming months she plans to reinvest most of the profit to establish her business.

loans.use: to buy an oven for her pastry business.

loans.name: Mrs. Khouern Villag Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people, who have selected Mrs. Khouern, who was born in 1978, to be the village bank president will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes that can increase their family's to be a high standard of living.

Mrs. Khouern and her husband, Mr. Phoeun, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they grow rice. They sell part of the rice yield and use the rest of the rice to support their family. Mr. Phoeun is also a construction worker. Mrs. Khouern would now like to buy a cow for breeding, but her savings money are insufficient.  Therefore, Mrs. Khouern would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to buy a cow.  She is the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in garment factories, another is a laborer, and the others are too young work or study.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Bokk Jom Group

texts.fr:
le groupe de solidarité BOKK JOM est créé le 16 février 2000. Il est composé de 16 femmes du même département administrative mais pas du même quartier.
